issues.description: The problem statement's UML and the solution implementation expect a Stock method named addToStockIngredients(StockIngredient) (used by SealSaloon.acceptSupplyDelivery), but the template Stock class defines addItem(StockIngredient) instead. This name/signature mismatch between the problem description/template/solution can confuse students about which method to call when adding a new StockIngredient (and may cause compile/test issues if the exercise tests or example code expect addToStockIngredients).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template Stock class consistent with the UML and solution by providing a method named addToStockIngredients(StockIngredient). Either rename the template's addItem method to addToStockIngredients, or add an addToStockIngredients wrapper that delegates to addItem. This keeps the template aligned with the problem description and the reference solution and avoids student confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) specifies a Stock method named addToStockIngredients(StockIngredient) to add a StockIngredient to the stock, but the template repository's Stock implementation provides a method named addItem(StockIngredient) instead. The solution repository implements addToStockIngredients. This inconsistent identifier for the same conceptual operation (adding a StockIngredient into the stock) can confuse students: the exercise instructions and UML refer to addToStockIngredients, yet the starter code exposes addItem, so students may search for or call a non-existent method name when mapping requirements to the template.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the template method addItem(StockIngredient) to addToStockIngredients(StockIngredient) so the starter code matches the problem statement and solution (or alternatively update the problem statement/UML to reference addItem). Keeping the method name addToStockIngredients in template will remove mapping confusion and align all artifacts.
